Entry (verbatim): Rebecca Ferguson was born in Stockholm, Sweden in 1983 to a Swedish father (Olov Sundström) and an English mother (Rosemary Ferguson), growing up bilingual and culturally mixed.
Her eccentric mother (who once helped the band ABBA translate song lyrics) encouraged her to try many activities, from gymnastics and tap dance to even playing bridge with elderly ladies.
Ferguson attended an arts-focused school with emphasis on singing and music.
At 15, she auditioned for a local soap opera (Nya Tider) and landed the lead role, leaving formal schooling.
After the soap ended, Ferguson worked normal jobs (nanny, shop clerk, restaurant hostess).
Olov Sundström (Swedish father).
Rosemary Ferguson (English mother; eccentric; once helped ABBA translate lyrics).
Nya Tider (Swedish daytime soap opera, 1999).
“Never told me that things aren’t possible.”
“Moved away from home, everything,”
She describes her career path as “a slow process,” taking time to discover her craft.
Source Section: Background & Early Life; Creative Passions & Work Ethic

Entry (verbatim): Parents’ unwavering support and “never told me that things aren’t possible” attitude instilled confidence and curiosity.
Rebellious independent streak.
Context / Notes: From moving out young and fame forcing her to grow up fast.

Entry (verbatim): Grounded, self-reliant personality and strong sense of realism about acting.
She didn’t “sharp-elbow” her way through Hollywood; instead, her career was “a slow process.”
The White Queen (2013), portrayed Queen Elizabeth Woodville.
Context / Notes: Earned wide recognition and Golden Globe nomination.

Entry (verbatim): Golden Globe nomination for Best Actress in a Miniseries for The White Queen (2013).
“It was my first ever international role. I moved away from home, from Sweden, and I lived in Bruges for six months. I played the Queen of England with an incredible crew.”
Mission: Impossible – Rogue Nation (2015), role: Ilsa Faust.
“Bam! There [Cruise] was in front of me.”
Performed most of her own stunts in Rogue Nation, with weeks of fight training.
Overcame lifelong fear of heights by doing 120-foot free-fall stunt at Vienna Opera House.
“I’m still patting myself on the shoulder for that one.”
Source Section: Career Breakthroughs; Creative Passions & Work Ethic

Entry (verbatim): Tom Cruise said: “Rebecca is enormously talented. When she decides to do something, she makes it happen.”
Cruise compared her blend of elegance and steel to a young Ingrid Bergman.
Mission: Impossible – Fallout (2018), reprise of Ilsa Faust.
Mission: Impossible – Dead Reckoning Part One (2023), reprise of Ilsa Faust.
The Girl on the Train (2016).
Florence Foster Jenkins (2016).
Context / Notes: Acted opposite Meryl Streep and Hugh Grant.

Entry (verbatim): The Greatest Showman (2017).
The Kid Who Would Be King (2019).
“I never started off thinking I was going to be an actress – it kind of happened and I enjoyed it.”
“After a while you get to a point where you can sift things out.”
Context / Notes: On becoming selective in role choice.

Entry (verbatim): Worked with director of The Usual Suspects and acted opposite idols like Meryl Streep.
“I’ve been so lucky and fortunate to work with many of the people who I have adored to watch.”
Doctor Sleep (2019), role: Rose the Hat.
Context / Notes: Won Fangoria Chainsaw Award for Best Supporting Actress.

Entry (verbatim): Fangoria Chainsaw Award for Best Supporting Actress, Doctor Sleep (2019).
Dune (2021), role: Lady Jessica.
Context / Notes: Denis Villeneuve expanded her role in Dune: Part Two.

Entry (verbatim): Denis Villeneuve described her as passionate, imaginative, with “no fear to walk into the unknown.”
Organized off-set excursions during Dune filming (e.g., Dead Sea boat trip).
Silo (2023), role: Juliette.
She initially turned down the lead role in Silo until script issues were fixed.
“That is success… being listened to.”
Context / Notes: On seeing her suggestions implemented on Silo.

Entry (verbatim): Nominations from the Saturn Awards and Satellite Awards for Silo.
Nordic Honorary Dragon Award at the 2022 Göteborg Film Festival.
Dune: Part Two (release 2023/24), reprise of Lady Jessica.
Peaky Blinders film adaptation.
Mentored early by Beatrice Järås; influenced by Sir John Hurt.
“Yet a new episode that I put into my backpack of life.”
Context / Notes: On how she views each career chapter.

Entry (verbatim): She has stated outright that she doesn’t particularly enjoy fame and is “completely” private.
She has managed to “always remain below the radar” even after appearing in major blockbusters.
“Not being recognised suits me.”
Anonymity is a “good thing” in her view.
She is known to live far from the Hollywood scene, making her home on a farm in the rural Swedish countryside.
For over a decade, she has kept her primary residence on a spacious farm in the Österlen region of southern Sweden.
“It’s the calm, it’s the trees, it’s the ocean, it’s the light… This is my part of the world.”
“I just love being in nature.”
Her property isn’t just a personal retreat but a communal haven with vegetable gardens, lambs, and treehouses for the kids.
“Where [the kids] can just run around… so much space for people to do whatever they want and just create.”
Context / Notes: On her vision for home life.

Entry (verbatim): Director Denis Villeneuve marveled at Ferguson’s relationship with reality after hearing how she casually biked to a children’s birthday party in a big wool hat and socks.
Villeneuve told her, “You’re a very grounded human being.”
She often returns home to Sweden after red-carpet trips and immediately resumes chores like taking out the garbage or biking to the grocery store.
She openly “avoids her own phone” whenever possible.
“I’m sick and tired of the device.”
She said it’s not technology itself she hates but her tendency to get over-involved with “400 things up in the air.”
By deliberately stepping back from social media and smartphones, she ensures she can focus on life.
She maintains an official Instagram account (under the nickname “Rex”), used sparingly.
She often forgets to post at all, preferring to stay semi-offline.
Off camera she is “sweary and bright, vibrant and loud,” radiating an easygoing charm.
Ferguson has a keen sense of humor and isn’t afraid to be playful or silly.
On set, she often jokes around and laughs freely – provided she feels comfortable with the people around her.
She is the type to “coo at other people’s kids and at other people’s dogs” in public.
She is prone to self-deprecating comedy, sharing funny anecdotes about embarrassing herself in front of co-stars.
Meeting actor Ewan McGregor for Doctor Sleep left her blushing like a starstruck teen and babbling awkwardly.
During Doctor Sleep rehearsals, she burst into an impromptu off-key singing game to tease McGregor, belting out “Stand by Me” loudly and off-pitch.
Ferguson’s willingness to create laughter – even at risk of looking silly – underscores her fun-loving, down-to-earth temperament.
Those who have interviewed her frequently remark how “prone to laughter” she is, with a ready joke and an approachable warmth.
Her humor never feels forced; it comes from a genuine place of joy and spontaneity.
During one interview, upon spotting that the journalist was using a phone app to transcribe, Ferguson blurted out, “Penis! Yep, there it is… Vagina! For equality…”
It was an outrageous, cheeky moment wholly initiated by her, dissolving formality into shared laughter.
Denis Villeneuve: “She loves to have fun… make jokes and make sure that everybody is comfortable.”
Whether playfully trolling a co-star or pulling a prank in an interview, Ferguson’s vibrant sense of humor helps create a convivial atmosphere around her.
Ferguson is known for her direct, straightforward manner of speaking, rarely sugarcoating her words.
She speaks her mind with refreshing candor, even on sensitive or controversial subjects.
“I like going straight for the point. I don’t like to waste time.”
She has emphasized that she doesn’t go looking for “strong women” roles, preferring to seek characters who are interesting, complex, and human.
“I don’t go looking for roles of strong women: I’m not looking for strong women, I’m looking for interesting people.”
Source Section: Direct & Authentic Communication; Personal Values & Lifestyle

Entry (verbatim): She stresses that she approaches roles with honesty and curiosity rather than attempting to project an image.
Colleagues and journalists alike remark on Ferguson’s raw authenticity – she is much the same in interviews as in private conversation.
“I don’t think he would like to act” (about her son).
She often interrupts herself mid-sentence if she feels she’s overexplaining, preferring simple directness.
Her interviews often include candid admissions and unfiltered opinions, setting her apart from actors who stick to rehearsed PR lines.
Her directness, though sharp at times, comes across as warm rather than abrasive – aided by her humor and laughter.
This authenticity has earned her respect among collaborators who value her honesty on and off set.
Ferguson has always carved her own path, guided by her instincts rather than by Hollywood expectations.
She never felt the need to relocate permanently to Los Angeles, preferring to remain rooted in Europe.
“I never wanted to be tied down to Hollywood.”
She has stated she values independence from the industry machine and refuses to bend her life around Hollywood norms.
Known for occasionally rebelling against industry pressure, she is quick to stand her ground when pushed.
“I don’t like being told what to do.”
She turned down roles she felt were repetitive or uninteresting, even when they were big opportunities.
“I turned down jobs that would have paid well but didn’t speak to me.”
Ferguson embraces mistakes and admits them freely rather than hiding them, underscoring her self-confidence.
“I don’t mind saying when I’ve fucked up.”
Her rebellious streak is not about arrogance but about maintaining autonomy, freedom, and honesty.
She speaks frankly with her son, preferring honesty and independence over strict parental control.
Ferguson is often described as poised, calm, and compassionate even under high-stress situations.
During high-pressure filming or interviews, she maintains a calm, collected demeanor.
“I want everyone around me to feel safe.”
She pays attention to the comfort of cast and crew, ensuring inclusivity and warmth.
“It’s about listening, it’s about making sure people are seen.”
Colleagues note her ability to absorb stress without passing it along, helping stabilize tense environments.
She demonstrates empathy in interviews, often deflecting attention from herself to acknowledge the work of others.
“I don’t want it to be about me all the time.”
This mix of compassion and steadiness strengthens her reputation as both approachable and reliable.
Family is her top priority; she repeatedly emphasizes her devotion to her children and partner.
“I believe in love.”
She has a son from a previous relationship and a daughter with her current partner.
She chooses to raise her children away from Hollywood’s spotlight.
She actively creates an environment where her children can roam, play, and grow up with nature around them.
“I don’t want my children to grow up on film sets.”
Ferguson prioritizes simplicity and balance in her lifestyle choices, avoiding unnecessary extravagance.
She describes a daily life of cooking, tending the farm, and spending quality time with her family.
She rarely speaks about her partner in detail, keeping her private life guarded.
Prefers rural calm over urban chaos, reinforcing her desire for balance.
She consistently emphasizes being true to herself, both privately and professionally.
Ferguson is known for her intense commitment and discipline when preparing for roles.
For Mission: Impossible, she trained extensively in combat, weapons handling, and stunts.
“When I decide to do something, I make it happen.”
She learns new skills quickly and immerses herself fully in the craft.
Ferguson finds great joy in the process of acting and storytelling.
“I love storytelling.”
She views acting as a continuous process of discovery rather than a perfected skill.
Directors often praise her willingness to collaborate and her imaginative ideas on set.
Denis Villeneuve said she has “no fear to walk into the unknown.”
She has been known to organize group activities for cast and crew to foster community.
She takes pride in doing her own stunts, seeing them as an extension of character building.
Belief in persistence and determination shapes both her personal and professional life.
Ferguson is widely seen as an actress who has built her career on authenticity, independence, and groundedness.
She consistently values truth over pretense, both in her personal life and her acting.
Independence remains central to her worldview — professionally, geographically, and personally.
She is admired for blending vulnerability with strength, humor with seriousness, independence with compassion.
Ferguson’s persona is shaped by her Swedish-English background, her grounded rural lifestyle, her independence, and her playful authenticity.
“So, how’s your sex life? Are you happy?”
Context / Notes: On her habit of asking blunt questions to break the ice.

Entry (verbatim): As executive producer on Silo, she emphasized listening and speaking plainly, with “zero diva behavior.”
“There is no book on how you lead. You listen and you follow.”
She openly discussed #MeToo and called it a good time in Hollywood as people push for equality.
“We are in a good time right now… a lot of discussions and I can feel it on the sets… hopefully it will continue.”
Denis Villeneuve teased that when things feel too safe, Ferguson “likes to throw a bomb” to test limits.
“When I feel safe, I just need to shake it up a bit and see if everything holds together.”
Context / Notes: On her impulse to stir things.

Entry (verbatim): “If you take [her] out… the film will have holes.”
Context / Notes: On what makes a female role worthwhile.

Entry (verbatim): “By questioning, by being a rebel… she changes the status quo… I love it.”
Married Rory St. Clair Gainer in a secret, intimate ceremony in 2018; son Isaac was ringbearer, daughter slept through vows.
“I’m not very religious. I believe in love.”

“I feel frustrated by the pitfall of doing things that are not completely different… It makes me see that I’m trying to put together something that is shaped by other people, and I want to break out of it.”
On a 2017 flight, she helped an unconscious passenger by taking charge, giving instructions, and reviving them.
“As soon as someone takes control, people feel safe.”
During Fallout, an aggressive co-star screamed at her; she cried, then confronted him and refused to work with him again.
“You can f** off! I never want to see you again.”
Context / Notes: On standing up to a bullying co-star.

Entry (verbatim): For Rose the Hat, she emphasized the character’s maternal love for her “gang,” making her more disturbing.
“All she really cared about was loving her gang equally as much as a mother cares for her child.”
“Every job I do is yet a new episode that I put into my backpack of life.”
“I come in and he’s hanging off a harness somewhere. He loves it. I don’t think he would like to act.”
Context / Notes: On her son visiting Mission: Impossible set.

Entry (verbatim): “If it’s a good cup of coffee, if my son is in a good mood, if it’s a lovely morning… it doesn’t have to be sunny.”
She loves cooking and often makes Swedish meatballs for her family.
“I rock [at cooking them], I really do… busy with my hands deep in minced meat.”
“We’ve constantly been in a shitshow.”
“Life… just moves and if you keep your eyes open then it’s all there in front of you.”
She praised Mission: Impossible sets for equality in stunts and training, even pre-#MeToo.
“We were training together and having fun together… the equality is already established on the set, which is fantastic.”
She admits “the most exciting aspect of a role is the research and prepping,” often breaking down scripts and working with coaches.
“I do a lot of prep work.”
Full name: Rebecca Louisa Ferguson Sundström.
Context / Notes: Biographical detail expanding beyond earlier rows.

Entry (verbatim): Born 19 October 1983 in Stockholm, Sweden.
Context / Notes: Birth date detail not included in prior file.

Entry (verbatim): Currently resides in Cookridge, Leeds (2025).
“Creating a role is script work and thinking about history, body, movement… then f***ing it all up a little bit.”
Context / Notes: On her creative method in approaching roles.

Entry (verbatim): “I wanted Jessica to be torn — a mother, a soldier, allegiance and love tearing her apart.”
Context / Notes: On shaping Lady Jessica in Dune.

Entry (verbatim): “I didn’t want to play a mum or a queen or a countess. I wanted to play a drug addict… I wanted to be seen as a real actor.”
Context / Notes: Reflecting her choices in avoiding stereotypical roles.

Entry (verbatim): “When I come home, I paddle board on the Thames… our home is always open for people to come and go.”
Context / Notes: On her family life and hospitality.

Entry (verbatim): “I can’t just eat f***ing vegetables. I don’t drink. I don’t do drugs. I’m now not smoking.”
Context / Notes: Speaking on her health and lifestyle habits.

Entry (verbatim): “I found these caffeinated, B6, B12-induced toothpicks.”
Context / Notes: Quirky personal habit mentioned in interviews.

Entry (verbatim): “Dick darts… dildo darts… burning goats.”
Context / Notes: Example of her unfiltered, playful sense of humor.

Entry (verbatim): “A tip: never wink at her, Rebecca Ferguson couldn’t return it!”
“I don’t get that many Swedish offers, give me a role.”
Context / Notes: On her Swedish identity and career opportunities.

Entry (verbatim): “Beyond the successes… I am careful to maintain my ties to my homeland.”
Context / Notes: Emphasizing her roots despite global career.

Entry (verbatim): “Her vulnerability was the most important moments for me.”
“I tried reading this book. It was hard… [Villeneuve] had such a vision.”
Context / Notes: On adapting to Dune under Villeneuve’s direction.

Entry (verbatim): “We interviewed Rebecca Ferguson, returning as Lady Jessica Atreides in Dune: Part Two.”
Context / Notes: Banter with Spanish host; reflects lighthearted press interactions.

Entry (verbatim): “Oscar Isaac in that chainmail… I couldn’t stop laughing. He looked magnificent, but also like a medieval knight lost on Arrakis.”
Context / Notes: On the Dune set; shows her humor and candidness.

Entry (verbatim): “Jason Momoa is like a Labrador puppy. You can’t not smile when he’s in the room.”
“The beard. Always the beard. How do you act opposite Oscar when that beard is taking up half the frame?”
“Ewan [McGregor] is the sweetest man. I once tripped in front of him, flat on my face, and he just helped me up while I was dying of embarrassment.”
Context / Notes: Funny anecdote; highlights her self-deprecating humor.

Entry (verbatim): “Yes, I am Swedish, not English. No, I don’t eat surströmming at breakfast.”
“Fear tells me I’m alive. If I stop feeling fear, I’ll stop growing.”
“Sometimes I ride too fast, sometimes I dive too deep — it’s reckless, but it’s also me.”
“I don’t have a plan for my career. I don’t sit and strategize. I choose what feels alive, what feels like it will teach me something.”
“Strength doesn’t mean being hard. Vulnerability is strength. That’s what I look for in the women I play.”
“You can’t control what people think of you. You can only control the work you put in and how you behave.”
“I don’t want to be known as the serious actress. I want to be known as someone who loves life, who laughs, who swears too much, who sometimes makes a fool of herself.”
Context / Notes: On how she wishes to be remembered.

Entry (verbatim): “At the end of the day, it’s about family, love, and a good laugh. That’s what matters.”
“Creating a role is about finding the history, the body, the movement… and then f*** ing it all up a little bit.”
“Every job I do is yet another episode I put into my backpack of life.”

“Sometimes you come with ideas, but with Lady Jessica it was so important to stick to the book. Denis had such a clear vision, and together we worked out: is she the protective mother, the trainer, or the woman who creates the disaster? Each moment demanded a different facet of her.”

“I didn’t know if the voice would work until I tried it. It had to come from somewhere deep — no mechanics, just resonance. I’d shout it, straight and loud, and Denis would play with the sound in post.”
“I said, you can f*** off. I never want to see you again. I’ll act to the back of your head.”
“You teach people how to treat you. That was one of the most important lessons I’ve ever been given.”
“I’m not scared of the consequence of speaking up. You should never have to walk into a workplace afraid of someone.”
“I like awkwardness. I like a bit of awkwardness — it’s like a mist in the air I like to breathe in. But it’s nothing I’m seeking or wanting.”
“throwing bombs”
“Sometimes I blurt things out. It’s like a moment where I think: I probably shouldn’t say this — and by that time, it’s already said.”
“Dick darts. Dildo darts. Burning goats. I mean, who comes up with that? Me, apparently.”
“I curse a lot. My mother hated it, but it’s who I am. It comes out when I’m nervous or excited.”
“I’m one of those stealth Swedes. People think I’m English — like Skarsgård, at least he has the name. I had many names: Rebecca Louisa Ferguson Sundström. I dropped one to make it easier.”
“My husband loves surströmming . He’ll go into the woods and open the can by himself as a joke. The smell is unbearable!”
“I’m sick and tired of the device. I put it away as much as I can.”
“I forget to post on Instagram. I don’t think about it, and then suddenly months go by.”
“I’d rather be in the garden, building something with my kids, than scrolling.”
“On the Creek Road in London, on a very fast bike… one mistake and I’m dead.”
“The first day Tom put me in a harness, pulled me up, and dropped me. I was petrified. I swore every bad word I knew.”
“That’s the job, right? You go into your fears and you break them down until you own them.”
“When I saw Oscar in the chain dress the first day I thought, that’s mine. I took it from him and gave him the suit.”
“It’s hard not to laugh when you’re acting opposite the beard. I had to overcome the beard to find the man.”
“The utmost depth of love — for her child, for her not-husband because he won’t marry her, but for her Duke. That’s what I related to in Jessica.”
“Fear is the little death that brings total obliteration. I will let it pass through me and over me, and where fear has gone, only I will remain.”
“Being on a movie set is sometimes like being in a high school cafeteria. You don’t know who to hang out with.”
“My mum made me do everything. Tap dancing, gymnastics, bridge — yes, the card game! She thought I should just try everything until something stuck.”
“I never thought I would be an actress. I was 15, there was a casting for a Swedish soap opera, and suddenly I became the lead. It was never the plan.”
“I grew up in Vasastan , Stockholm. Summers were spent on the Swedish coast — that rhythm of the sea, the light, the calm — it’s always with me.”
“When people recognise me, I don’t always understand why. I still feel like me — biking to the store, taking out the garbage. That’s what I love about living outside Hollywood.”
“I don’t have that need for attention. My joy comes from the work, not from the fame.”
“Denis [Villeneuve] is meticulous, but also so warm. He’ll come up with an idea, and then ask you to surprise him. That mix is what makes his sets so creative.”
“Mike Flanagan wanted Rose [the Hat] to be seductive and terrifying at the same time. That was the key — her joy in what she did.”
“Tom [Cruise] pushes you but in the safest way possible. He’ll never ask you to do something he hasn’t tested himself. That creates so much trust.”
“Jessica is a mother, a concubine, a Bene Gesserit , a political tool. Which one is she in each moment? That was the puzzle I loved.”
“Rose the Hat was a delight to play because she scared me. I thought, how can I enjoy her the way she enjoys what she does? That’s where the menace came from.”
“Ilsa Faust was written as an equal to Ethan Hunt. That was the attraction — she wasn’t just a sidekick or a love interest.”
“I’m clumsy. I say the wrong thing, I trip, I laugh at myself. That’s me.”
“I swear. A lot. My mother used to tell me off for it, but it’s part of my rhythm. Sometimes it’s the only word that fits.”
“I like to keep sets alive. If it’s too serious, I’ll crack a joke or do something silly.”
“I keep my base in Sweden because I want my kids to grow up with the sea, the woods, the calm. That’s where I recharge.”
“I’ll do a film, then I’ll disappear for a while. That’s important — otherwise I lose myself.”
“Home is people walking in and out, kids running around, food on the stove. That’s what I protect.”
“The Vienna Opera House jump… I was crying with fear. I have vertigo. But I did it.”
“I think I thrive in awkward moments. They make me feel alive.”
“I don’t filter well. If I think it, it might come out. And then I deal with the fallout.”
“Sets can be political. You don’t always know who to sit with at lunch. But I’ve learned to just be myself, and that’s enough.”
“Fear is a tool. It’s never going away, so I invite it in. I let it sit with me until it becomes part of me.”
“Jessica is the utmost depth of love — for her child, for her not-husband because he won’t marry her, but for her Duke. That’s what I held on to.”
“The voice had to come from somewhere real, somewhere inside. It wasn’t about shouting. It was about channeling something deeper.”
“When I saw the stillsuits for the first time I thought, oh my God, they’re beautiful. And then after a week in the desert, they were hell.”
“The fun with Timmy [Chalamet] was watching him grow into Paul. He carried the weight, and you could see it in his eyes.”
“I don’t want to be typecast. I want to keep shifting, keep surprising people — and myself.”
“Some jobs are huge, others are tiny, but they all matter because they all change me.”
“I’d rather fail at something ambitious than succeed at something safe.”
“I once said ‘dick darts’ on a live panel. I have no filter. It just came out.”
“I’m private, but I’m not closed. I’ll share, but only the things that feel true to me.”
Mother: Rosemary Ferguson, originally from Britain, worked with ABBA translating song lyrics.
Context / Notes: Adds detail on mother and ABBA connection.

Entry (verbatim): Father: Olov Sundström, Swedish businessman.
Has siblings (not often discussed publicly).
Context / Notes: New family detail absent from prior profile.

Attended Adolf Fredrik’s Music School, focused on singing and choir.
Worked briefly as a model in teen years, appearing in magazines.
Practiced dance styles including ballet, tap, jazz, and Argentine tango.
Joined a local bridge club, often playing with elderly women as a child.
First acting role at 15 in Swedish soap opera Nya tider.

Entry (verbatim): Starred in Swedish horror film Drowning Ghost (2004).
Relocated to Simrishamn in Österlen, southern Sweden, where she worked as a nanny before international breakthrough.

Entry (verbatim): Appeared in short-lived series Wallander (Sweden).
Appeared in series Nya tider led to recognition, but also typecasting risk.
Appeared in The White Queen (2013) as Elizabeth Woodville, breakout international role.
“If nudity is necessary for a role, I will do it, but only if it makes sense.”

Appeared in Swedish film Vi (2013).

Appeared in The Greatest Showman (2017), playing Jenny Lind.

Praised for performance in Dune, highlighted for vulnerability and strength.

Entry (verbatim): Expressed interest in stage work in future career.
Known to often go barefoot during interviews and events.
Enjoys cooking, especially Swedish meatballs.
Has a fear of snakes.
Fluent in Swedish and English.
Sometimes uses French and German in roles.
Describes herself as introverted but candid.
“I am not interested in playing stereotypes; I want roles that feel human and complicated.”
“Strength comes from vulnerability, not just toughness.”
Faced criticism in 2023 after comments on Swedish TV show Efter fem perceived as racially insensitive.
“I am deeply sorry, my words came out wrong, and I hurt people.”
Context / Notes: Public apology after Efter fem controversy.

Entry (verbatim): Married Rory St. Clair Gainer in 2018, in a private ceremony.
Son Isaac (from earlier relationship) and daughter with Rory.
Keeps a home in Österlen, Sweden, returning often for peace and grounding.
Enjoys paddleboarding on the Thames when at home in England.
“I guard my privacy. I don’t want my children or partner in the spotlight.”
“Acting is what I do, not who I am. Who I am is a mother, a partner, a friend.”
“I can be blunt, but I think honesty is kinder in the end.”
“Don’t ask me to sing. Jenny Lind was movie magic, not me.”
“I swear too much, and I’m fine with that.”
“I don’t want to be put in a box, ever. That’s when I’ll stop.”
Continues to balance large-scale Hollywood projects with smaller European films.
Frequently collaborates with directors who value strong, complex female roles.
Has turned down roles that felt one-dimensional, even if lucrative.
“Fear tells me I am alive; I welcome it.”
“Preparation is where the work is. Filming is the reward.”
“I love research — it’s where characters become flesh.”
Known for playful improvisation on set, surprising cast and crew.
“Sometimes I just throw in a line to see if anyone notices.”
“I believe in love, not labels.”
“I want my children to see me as present, not just as an actress.”
“Every role should scare me a little. That’s when I know it’s worth doing.”
“Awards are lovely, but they’re not why I act.”
Plans to explore producing more projects after Silo.
Respected in industry for professionalism and lack of diva behavior.
Valued by colleagues for humor and warmth off-camera.
“Life is messy, and that’s what makes it beautiful.”
“I don’t want perfection; I want truth.”
Has expressed desire to one day return to Swedish stage.
Cast in the Peaky Blinders film (Netflix) with Cillian Murphy (filming wrapped).
Silo officially renewed through Seasons 3 & 4; Season 2 aired Nov 15, 2024 – Jan 17, 2025; S3 wrapped May 2025.
Mercy (sci-fi thriller) release moved to Jan 23, 2026; production wrapped May 2024.
Venice Film Festival (Mar 19, 2025) red carpet appearance.
Mission: Impossible – The Final Reckoning (2025) screened at Cannes out of competition.
Dune Part II streaming release on Max set for Jul 30, 2025; Dune 3 filming early 2026, French release Dec 16, 2026.
“One of the happiest jobs I’ve ever done.”
“I’m not worried about the consequence of speaking up or saying no or coming forward.”
“I’m very much what’s on the page; the story needs to be there.”
“I got phone calls from amazing costars… ‘You understand what you’ve done, right?’”
“You teach people how to treat you.”
“I said you can f--- off… I’ll act to the back head.”
“I have no problem using my voice and I’m not scared of the consequences.”
“Dick darts… burning goats.”
“On the Creek Road in London on a very fast bike… one mistake and I’m dead.”
“I have it especially made to me because I’m claustrophobic.”
“On using the voice: very forcefully… straight and loud… resonance.”
Avoids elevators and prefers to take stairs, even several flights.
“I always walk the stairs, I don’t like elevators.”
Rebecca has claustrophobia.
“I am claustrophobic, so they had to make the stillsuit less tight for me.”
Context / Notes: On modifying costume for her condition.

Entry (verbatim): She kept her stillsuit from Dune: Part Two.
“I kept my suit! It’s in my home.”
She occasionally steals props from sets as mementos.
“I stole a rock. Which apparently is bad juju.”
Context / Notes: On taking a rock from the desert set.

Entry (verbatim): She jokes about props and souvenirs in interviews, showing candidness with audiences.
Uses humor to soften discussion of personal fears.
“I’m claustrophobic, but you just… laugh about it, don’t you?”
“I’m the worst person to bring to a horror movie. I scream, I jump, I grab.”
Context / Notes: On her reactions in horror films.

Entry (verbatim): She admits she is very jumpy and reactive when watching horror movies.
“Don’t sit next to me — I will claw your arm.”
Context / Notes: Playful exaggeration about watching horror movies.

Entry (verbatim): “I’m a terrible liar. You see it all over my face.”
Known for being a poor liar; struggles to conceal feelings.
“I’ve got helmets, swords… I’m like a kleptomaniac of film sets.”
Keeps various props from productions including helmets and swords.
“I need to feel scared when I take on a new role.”
Selects roles that frighten her; fear is a key criterion.
“If I’m comfortable, I’m not learning.”
Context / Notes: On personal growth and work ethic.

Entry (verbatim): “I swear too much, and I don’t care.”
Openly acknowledges swearing frequently, embraces it as part of her identity.
“When I use the Voice, it has to come from my gut, not my throat.”
Practices Bene Gesserit Voice from deep resonance, not throat projection.
“Denis kept saying: lower, lower, think resonance, think command.”
Context / Notes: On Villeneuve’s direction for the Voice.

Entry (verbatim): Denis Villeneuve guided her to deepen tone and use resonance for Voice scenes.
“Jessica is torn — a mother, a soldier, a lover, allegiance pulling her apart.”
Views Lady Jessica as conflicted between motherhood, soldier’s duty, and loyalty.
“The worm was so bloody big I thought it would swallow the set.”
Joked about the sandworm prop size on set.
“I had sand everywhere — in my ears, my underwear, everywhere.”
Complains humorously about sand getting everywhere during desert filming.
“I might have taken a worm tooth. Just one.”
Admitted to keeping a fake sandworm tooth as memorabilia.
“I don’t want perfection — I want it raw.”
“If it’s easy, I get bored.”
Avoids “easy” roles; looks for difficult challenges.
“We were dying in that heat — helmets fogging, sweating buckets.”
Desert shoots caused extreme heat and discomfort in gear.
“Timothée looked like a wilted flower — poor thing.”
Teased Timothée Chalamet for struggling with desert filming heat.
“And me? I just swore and drank water.”
Managed desert filming by cursing and staying hydrated.
“I was 15 and I got a call from a modeling agency.”
At age 15 she was contacted by a modeling agency.
“I thought, why not? I’ll try it.”
Entered modeling as a teenager with curiosity and openness.
“I got cast in Nya Tider with no training.”
Cast in Nya Tider without formal training.
“I learned on the job, very fast, or I would have been fired.”
Learned acting under pressure during first role; adaptation was survival.
“They flew me to Morocco to meet Tom Cruise.”
Flown to Morocco to meet Tom Cruise for Mission: Impossible.
“There was a camel waiting for me in the desert.”
Part of Mission: Impossible audition included arriving to a camel in the desert.
“I was terrified of the stunt test.”
Had to undergo a stunt test during Mission: Impossible casting.
“I swore at Tom Cruise when he told me to jump.”
Context / Notes: On reacting to Cruise during stunts.

Entry (verbatim): Swore at Tom Cruise when urged to perform a stunt jump.

Subtype/Category: Career / The Girl on the Train
Entry (verbatim): “I wanted to work with Emily Blunt.”
Took role in The Girl on the Train because she wanted to work with Emily Blunt.
“I practiced my American accent every day.”
Context / Notes: On preparation for The Girl on the Train.

Entry (verbatim): Practiced American accent daily for The Girl on the Train.
“I was in awe of Meryl Streep.”
Worked alongside Meryl Streep in Florence Foster Jenkins.
“I just watched her, studied how she worked.”
Studied Meryl Streep’s working methods on set.
“Daniel Espinosa called me about Life.”
Director Daniel Espinosa approached her about film Life.
“We trained to float, to counter every movement.”
Learned to simulate floating and counter-movements for zero-gravity acting.
“It was exhausting — every gesture had a reaction.”
Found zero-gravity acting exhausting due to constant counter-reactions.
“The director came in with a TV under his arm.”
Director Michael Gracey pitched The Greatest Showman using a TV under his arm.
“They wanted me to sing, but I fought to have Loren Allred’s voice.”
Refused to sing for Jenny Lind, insisted on Loren Allred’s vocals instead.
“I was terrified — everyone thought I’d be singing live.”
Felt terrified audiences would expect her to sing Jenny Lind’s parts live.
“Hugh Jackman was extraordinary, so generous.”
Praised Hugh Jackman’s generosity and professionalism on The Greatest Showman.
“I was pregnant while filming Mission.”
Filmed Mission: Impossible while pregnant.
“I was throwing up between takes.”
Context / Notes: On dealing with pregnancy sickness during filming.

Entry (verbatim): Experienced morning sickness during filming, vomiting between takes.
“Sean Harris said, ‘It’s a fanny fart.’”
Shared a crude joke from Sean Harris about pregnancy discomfort.
“I had to play someone evil while being a mother.”
Struggled emotionally to play Rose the Hat while being a mother.
“The child’s screams went through me — I nearly stopped.”
Deeply affected by child actor’s screams during filming Doctor Sleep.
“Denis is a visionary — he sees the whole world.”
Described Denis Villeneuve as a visionary director.
“The heat was unbearable, helmets fogging, people fainting.”
Desert filming on Dune was unbearably hot, caused helmets to fog and crew to faint.
“The worm was so enormous it felt alive.”
Described sandworm scale as overwhelming and lifelike.
“I feel I’ve grown so much as an actor from this.”
Feels Dune helped her grow significantly as an actor.
“Tom thinks of the audience first; I think of the character first.”
Contrasts Tom Cruise’s audience-first approach with her own character-first philosophy.
“Dick darts. Dick darts.”
“Boning goats. That’s where I stop.”
“Burning goats.”
“I can’t stop myself sometimes, I just blurt it out.”
Known for making up playful or absurd swearing expressions (e.g., “dick darts,” “boning goats”).
Admits she blurts things impulsively, sometimes without filter.
“I swear too much, and I don’t care.”
Comfortable with frequent swearing, embraces it as part of identity.
“On the Creek Road in London on a very fast bike… one mistake and I’m dead.”
Described biking stunts in London as extremely dangerous — “one mistake and I’m dead.”
“I got phone calls from amazing costars saying, ‘You understand what you’ve done, right?’”

“You teach people how to treat you.”
Believes people set the standard for how they’re treated.
“I have no problem using my voice and I’m not scared of the consequences.”
Comfortable asserting herself even when consequences may follow.
“I said you can f--- off. I’ll act to the back head.”
Once bluntly told off a colleague, showing refusal to be disrespected.
“I tried to read Dune and I couldn’t finish it.”
Initially struggled to read Frank Herbert’s Dune.
“Denis is a visionary, he sees everything.”
Praised Denis Villeneuve as visionary with complete world vision.
“Jessica is a mother, a soldier, a lover — all at once.”
Describes Jessica as multifaceted: mother, soldier, lover.
“Fear is the mind-killer.”
Quoted Dune’s iconic “fear is the mind-killer” mantra during interview.
“Oscar Isaac… I stroked his beard, it was glorious.”
Joked about Oscar Isaac’s beard on set.
“Josh Brolin made me laugh constantly.”
Found Josh Brolin consistently funny on set.
“Jason Momoa is like a big puppy.”
Described Jason Momoa as puppy-like.
“Oscar and I couldn’t stop giggling.”
Shared laughter and banter with Oscar Isaac on set.
“Jessica’s love and loyalty is what drives her.”
Believes Jessica is driven by love and loyalty.
“I’m claustrophobic, I need doors open.”
Suffers claustrophobia, requires open doors.
“Doctor Sleep was one of the hardest things I’ve done.”
Found Doctor Sleep extremely challenging.
“That beard! I could live in it.”
Made playful comments about Oscar Isaac’s beard.
“Surströmming is the worst smell in the world.”
Identifies with Swedish background, jokes about surströmming.
“Denis says I throw bombs — I blurt things without thinking.”
Acknowledges blurting impulsively; Denis Villeneuve teased her about it.
“I say the wrong thing all the time. It’s embarrassing.”
Often feels embarrassed about blurting awkward things.
“The Voice comes from deep down, it’s resonance.”
Explains the Voice as resonance from deep inside.
“It’s not shouting, it’s commanding.”

Entry (verbatim): Distinguishes Voice as command, not volume.
“We live Mission. It’s our life when we shoot.”
Describes filming Mission as all-consuming.
“It’s Mission on crack.”
Called Dead Reckoning “Mission on crack” to convey intensity.
“Tom thinks audience first, I think character first.”
Reiterated her character-first vs. Cruise’s audience-first philosophy.
“Silo is one of the happiest jobs I’ve done.”
Praised Silo as one of her happiest experiences.
